column4: I want to install windows on a separate partition.  I currently have only ubuntu.  So I'm wondering, will the windows installation give me the option of creating a separate partition?  Or should I create one before I attempt to install?
A user-friendly tool for the task is gparted.
fukas: how do I do that?  could you either explain it, or link me to something that will explain it?
Type "sudo apt-get install gparted" in a terminal.
Be aware that Windows doesn't like to be on anything other than the first partition.
fukas: so windows will automatically install to the first partition without askin?
It should ask, but it won't really give you much choice.
fukas: so how do I actually create a new partition.  I assume I have to first resize my current one but the resize button is grayed out.
That brings up an issue that I forgot: you can't make changes to a drive that is in use.
You will have to do it from the Live CD, or something else.
fukas: so could I just right click the partition and choose the unmount option?
No, because Ubuntu is running off it right now.
fukas: ok thanks for all your help, gonna get started :)
fukas: 1 last question.  It should work just fine if I use a gutsy liveCD to do the partition, even though I'm on intrepid   right?
